Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-Poland Project Development: Research on Rare Horseshoe Crabs in a Jurassic (160-145 million years old) Fossil Deposit in Poland
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to initiate a U.S.-Polish collaboration between Dr. Rodney M. Feldmann at Kent State University, Ohio, and Dr. Blazej Blazejowski, at the Polish Academy of Sciences' Institute of Paleobiology, Warsaw. Together, they will examine the recent discovery of over 100 specimens of ~160-145 million year old horseshoe crab fossils from the Kcynia Formation in the Owadów-Brezizinki quarry located in central Poland. The U.S.-Polish team expects their exploratory field and laboratory research to shed new light on the evolution and ecology of horseshoe crabs, (limulines) a group that has had a very long geological history, but has been poorly represented in the fossil record. With a few exceptions, abundant deposits of such specimens are extremely rare. Access to the recently discovered locality in Poland presents an exceptional opportunity to learn more about ancient horseshoe crab evolution and ecology and how this might affect modern coastal environments.

At the Owadów-Brezizinki site in Poland, the fossils are preserved as whole animals. Some specimens are preserved with articulated appendages exposed on underlying body surfaces. Therefore, the Polish and U.S. researchers expect to begin to characterize growth patterns, study molt stages, determine gender, and explore group behavior. Preliminary technical results will probe several areas of horseshoe paleobiology with the goal of testing whether today's limulines are truly "living fossils." Horseshoe crabs stand out as one of the most intriguing and ancient elements of arthropod fauna not only as ancients, but because in the modern era they have attracted interest of researchers due to their rhythmic patterns of locomotion, photoreceptors, immune system components, and general ecological significance and commercial potential.

This developmental U.S.-Polish collaboration will engage a U.S. graduate student in well tested study techniques and field practices. The team's initial findings are expected to help explain the factors that led to remarkable preservation and define the direction for follow-on cooperative research to add to our basic understanding of the diversity of horseshoe crabs ~160-145 million years ago. Results will be published in reviewed, international journals and new data entered into the Paleobiology Database. Altogether, the broader impacts of this international exploratory, collaborative and educational effort are expected to advance our fundamental knowledge in paleontology, with potential contributions to future paleoecological, hydrodynamic, and cuticle research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of our research was to study, describe, and interpret rare fossil horseshoe crabs of Jurassic age in Poland. Additionally, the research was designed to develop a new collaboration with Polish scientists and to introduce graduate students to working in an international arena. Although horseshoe crabs have had an exceedingly long fossil record, extending back into the Paleozoic Era, remains of the creatures are quite rare. Living forms are often referred to as "living fossils". Working in collaboration with scientists from the Polish Academy of Sciences, new species were recognized and the geographic range of Jurassic forms was extended into Poland.  Because horseshoe crabs of Jurassic age are also known from the famous Solnhofen Limestone in Germany, a comparison of the Polish species with that from Germany was conducted.  This aspect of the work was extremely valuable because it provided clear evidence that the species in the two localities were different from one another.  Perhaps more significant, the comparison made it possible to develop a list of morphological characters that will be used to insert into a computer program called PAUP in order to analyze the phylogenetic relationships of all species of horseshoe crabs throughout the Mesozoic and Cenozoic, that is, the last 250 million years of Earth history. This outcome extends well beyond the initial goals of the grant and demonstrates the importance of the research.  As a serendipitous outcome of the field work on the horseshoe crabs, the principal investigators discovered remains of a fossil lobster that represents the only member of an entire family of lobsters thus far known from Poland. Publication of a research paper on the fossil lobster, a masters thesis describing the Polish lobsters, and a presentation of the results at an international paleontological meeting has assured that the broader scientific community has access to the results. Success of the collaboration with the principal Polish scientist is documented by his interest in coming to Kent State University to continue working on the research with the principal investigators. Horseshoe crabs, by virtue of their long geologic history, have been significant members of shallow marine environments as scavengers and low-level predators. Documenting their evolutionary history and their physical adaptations provides essential insight into survival strategies of this ancient group.
